body:
I'd like to contribute and I'm starting it.
Edit: I'm assuming I need some kind of approval to publish the branch before the PR since I get a 403?

Hi @Augure34 Thanks for taking this issue. I did not see the edit, as we only get notifications about new messages, but not for edits.

Regarding your question then I'm guessing that you have just cloned this repo directly which is the reason why you cannot push the branch (only members of this project can create branches in this repo). So you'll need to:
* create a fork of this repo,
* clone your fork to your computer,
* create the changes on a new branch,
* push this branch to github,
* create the PR
This is described in more detail in e.g. https://thenewstack.io/getting-legit-with-git-and-github-your-first-pull-request/

Hey @mikkelbu, thanks you for your help (and the link to the article).
I've done this small modification and created a PR, however I wanted to extend the code coverage to this case as well as making sure I didn't break anything, but some tests are already failing without any changes. Is it normal? Or should I look for something on my side of things?

Thanks again

issue.title: Better error messages for generic test with type parameters

body:
Hi @Augure34 I can take a look at it tonight (in 4 hours time), but if it is the failing tests on the build server then I don't think it is your fault (only Linux is failing), but I've not looked at your changes yet. If you have local failing tests then I'm more worried ðŸ˜„.

Ps you can run the tests by invoking `build.ps1 -t Test` if you are on windows and similarly using `build.sh` for Linux, see e.g. https://github.com/nunit/nunit/blob/master/BUILDING.md.
Thank you I'll have a look with my local changes, don't waste your time on this it's probably my fault :) I was using VS test explorer, I may get a different result with your script

I have 6 errors in unit tests using the powershell script. They are due to my computer culture being set in french, failing string checks in exception messages that's all.

VS tests explorer launch tests that are meant to fail that's why I was so worried :)

The build output from DevOps isn't very helpful though (no failed tests name) I guess I need you to check the Tests runs report ;).

Regarding the 6 errors, please create an issue for them with the failing tests, as this should be corrected, but not as part of this PR. We have had the problem before (in nunit/nunit#2895 and nunit/nunit#2228) and we also have an issue for a more robust solution - nunit/nunit#2900.

Regarding executing all tests in VS test explorer, then you are correct, as far as I can remember we have that "issue" both in the Console - nunit/nunit-console#347 - and in the framework - nunit/nunit#2297.

Ps. I've forced a rebuild on the build-server and also linked the PR with this issue (by editing the first comment in the PR).
I've been looking for a **Good First Issue**. Can I help in any way?

Hi @seanpoulter and welcome. Thanks for taking an interest in this ticket, you're very welcome to contribute. It looks like @mikkelbu has already given a bit of guidance above, but please feel free to reach out if you have any questions.
@seanpoulter You can probably base your work on the old PR #3377 (perhaps even base your branch upon @Augure34 existing work, so that he will also get credit)
